 As with many of the Christian elements and symbols the cross goes deeper than what appears on the surface. The cross is a paradox, a "collision of opposites."* (literally and figuratively) It is "the paradox of the impotence of omnipotence and the hopelessness of the hope of the world."**
 
 It is a "tool of murder" at the same time it is a tool of salvation. It is where Jesus became weak to become strong (to put a spin on Paul's description of his own trials). It is where hate was absorbed and not returned (as is the usual reaction) and then transformed into love.* It is where the King of Kings suffered the death of the lowest serf and criminal. But this was the greatest act of humility he could have shown. In this greatest act of humility was the greatest act of love. "For there is no greater love than a man give up his life for another." As Jesus told us about the greatest love, he also practiced what he preached, being the ultimate preacher. Because he preached it as something to follow, the crucifixion does not stay distant and remote as a simple, past tense, historical fact for believers. It rather becomes a perpetual reminder and an encouragement to us to take up our own cross in showing this love for others. It is a reminder to "be obedient unto death" as was Jesus.
 
 So "It is true, and even tautological, to say that the cross is the crux of the whole matter." For "the timber of that terrible tree was the death of God and the life of man."***
 
 *Father Richard Rohr
 
 **G.K. Chesterton in The Way of the Cross A Commentary by Gilbert Keith Chesterton
 
 ***G.K. Chesterton in The Everlasting Man
